questions.question_text:
A company needs to automatically delete sensitive information after seven years. This could delete almost a million records every day.
How can this be achieved?

choices.D: Schedule an @future process to query records older than seven years, and then recursively invoke itself in 1,000 record batches to delete them
choices.B: Perform a SOSL statement to find records older than 7 years, and then delete the entire result set
choices.C: Schedule a batch Apex process to run every day that queries and deletes records older than seven years
choices.A: Use aggregate functions to query for records older than seven years, and then delete the AggregateResult objects

discussion.content: The correct Ans should be C

Selected Answer: C
Aggregate queries can only query aggregated information, not single rows.

comments.content: But you still cannot run flow when records is undeleted, so Trigger seems to be a better option

discussion.content: Flow is the correct answer as you can now trigger flow on record deletion as well.

Apex trigger is correct answer.
Can't trigger workflow, process builder and flow with delete record event.

questions.question_text:
An org contains two custom objects: Building__c and Office__c. Office__c has a Lookup field to Building__c.
A developer is asked to automatically populate the Number_of_Offices__c field on the Building__c object with the count of related Office__c records anytime an
Office__c record is created or deleted. The developer cannot modify the field types.
Which solutionmeets the requirements?
Which scenario requires a developer to use an Apex callout instead of Outbound Messaging?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Outbound Messaging is designed for SOAP-based web services.
If the target system has a REST API, an Apex callout is required.
A. The target system uses a REST API.

choices.C: The target system uses a SOAP API.
choices.A: The target system uses a REST API.
choices.B: The callout needs to be asynchronous.
choices.D: The callout needs to be invoked from a Workflow Rule.

questions.question_text:
A developer has a requirement to query three fields (Id, Name, Type) from an Account and First and Last names for all Contacts associated with the Account.

Which option is the preferred optimized method to achieve this for the Account named ‘Ozone Electronics’?

choices.B: Account a = [SELECT ID, Name, Type, (SELECT FirstName, LastName FROM Contacts) FROM Account WHERE name=‘Ozone Electronics’ LIMIT 1];
choices.A: Account a = [SELECT ID, Name, Type FROM Account WHERE name=‘Ozone Electronics’]; list lContacts = [SELECT firstname, lastname FROM Contact WHERE accounted=:a.ID];
choices.C:
list lContacts = new list();
for (Contact c :[SELECT firstname, lastname, Account.Name, Account.ID, Account.Type FROM Contact WHERE Account.Name=‘ozone electronics’]) ( lContacts.add(c); )
choices.D: list lAccounts = [SELECT ID, Name, Type FROM Account JOIN (SELECT ID, firstname, lastname FROM Contact WHERE contact.account.name = ‘ozone electronics’)];

discussion.content: If you still figuring out like me previously, take a look that in question there is a information about SINGLE Account, so LIMIT 1 shoudnt be problematic and Ans B is good option

Selected Answer: B
"Preferred optimized method" can only be B
I think the correct answer is B.

questions.question_text:
Just prior to a new deployment, the Salesforce Administrator, who configured a new order fulfillment process feature in a developer sandbox, suddenly left the company.

As a part of the UAT cycle, the users had fully tested all of the changes in the sandbox and signed off on them; making the Order fulfillment feature ready for its go-live in the production environment.

Unfortunately, although a Change Set was started, it was not completed by the former administrator. A developer is brought in to help finish the deployment.

What should the developer do to identify the configuration changes that need to be moved into production?

choices.C: Set up Continuous Integration and a Git repository to automatically merge all changes from the sandbox metadata with the production metadata.
choices.D: Use the Metadata API and a supported development IDE to push all of the configuration from the sandbox into production to ensure no changes are lost.
choices.A: In Salesforce setup, look at the last modified date for every object to determine which should be added to the Change Set.
choices.B: Leverage the Setup Audit Trail to review the changes made by the departed Administrator and identify which changes should be added to the Change Set.

discussion.content: In real life he should take a look on requirements included in sprint scope and them take a look on particular components and create bundle.

Selected Answer: B
Personally, B is very dangerous and never happens in the real world.
